titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Henry O'Reilly Papers
1832-1873 (Bulk 1844-1860)
MS 464
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rohinie J. Munzel

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from oreilly02MH.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-02T16:03-0400

did.abstract: The Papers of Henry O'Reilly, dating from 1832 to 1873, consist of 21 linear feet of material. The bulk of these papers date from 1844 to 1860. The O'Reilly Papers contain the following types of material: business and personal correspondence (letters, telegraph messages), minutes, proceedings, organizational documents (charters, by-laws, articles of incorporation and association), financial documents (bills, receipts, invoices, expenditure sheets, accounts, bank drafts, promissory notes, inventories, stock certificates), legal documents (contracts, conveyances, indentures, deeds, leases, affidavits, depositions, insurance policies, mortgages, memoranda), notes, reports, scrapbooks, and printed material (pamphlets, proofs, circulars, flyers, clippings).

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing. Send permission requests, citing the name of the collection from which you wish to quote, to
Library Director
The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Henry O'Reilly Papers, MS 464, the New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

chronitem.event: Born in Carrickmacross, Province of Ulster, Ireland
Came to New York, New York, Learned printer's trade
Assistant Editor of the New York Patriot
Editor of the Rochester Daily Advertiser
Appointed Deputy Collector and Inspector for the District of Genesee, New York
Began advocating rebuilding and enlargement of the Erie Canal
Appointed Post Master of Rochester, Published Sketches of Rochester
President of Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association
Recording Secretary, New York State Agricultural Society
Entered into contract with Samuel F.B. Morse and Amos Kendall for erecting telegraph lines in the United States
Established Irish and American Steamship Company
Organized Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company

bioghist.p: Henry O'Reilly was born in Carrickmacross, Province of Ulster, Ireland on Feb. 6, 1806 to a merchant and the daughter of a physician. In 1816, the family emigrated to New York. After working as an apprentice in the printing trade including several years as an assistant editor of the New York Patriot, in 1826 O'Reilly was appointed editor of the Rochester, NY, Daily Advertiser. Within a year, O'Reilly gained notice in the anti-Masonic uproar that followed the kidnapping and murder of William Morgan. In 1832, he was appointed Deputy Collector and Inspector for the District of Genesee, NY. He published numerous circulars and pamphlets on current events and issues, and in 1838 Sketches of Rochester, with Incidental Notices of Western New York. In that same year, O'Reilly was appointed Post Master of Rochester. From the 1830s through the 1850s, he was heavily involved in civic and political organizations, serving as the President of the Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association, Recording Secretary of the New York State Agricultural Society, and Chairman of the Clinton League.

O'Reilly's commercial activities were similarly energetic and varied. In 1833, he threw his support behind improvements to the Erie Canal. In 1845, he contracted with Samuel F.B. Morse and Amos Kendall in the planned construction of telegraph wires from eastern Pennsylvania to the Great Lakes. Legal difficulties ended his involvement with the enterprise, despite his erection of over 8,000 miles of wire. In 1851, O'Reilly established the Irish and American Steamship Company; in 1854, he organized the Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company.

O'Reilly was married to Marcia Brooks, daughter of General Micah Brooks; they had one son, Henry Brooks O'Reilly, who was killed in the Battle of Williamsburg, 1862. Late in his life, O'Reilly changed the spelling of his surname to O'Rielly; additional papers of O'Reilly may be found under this variant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Papers of Henry O'Reilly, 1832-1873 consist of 21 linear feet of material. The bulk of the papers date from 1844 to 1860 and include the following forms: business and personal correspondence, minutes, proceedings, organizational records, financial records, legal records, notes, reports, scrapbooks and printed matter.

The O'Reilly Papers document the diverse activities of Henry O'Reilly in Rochester, NY; the Genesee District; and New York State. Specific topics addressed include: the establishment of telegraph lines; the development, improvement and operations of the transportation industry, particularly canals, steamships and railroads; local and state politics; civic and cultural organizations; journalism; typography; American Indians; agriculture; government reform; the postal service; public schools; land purchases in Western Virginia; and the military career of O'Reilly's son.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence within series are usually arranged alphabetically for letters received, chronologically for letters sent. Unidentified letters received and correspondence between others arranged chronologically.
The documents have been arranged in twenty-three series. Many of the series have been arranged in subseries.

list.item: Series III: Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company, 1849-1858
Series VI: New York State Agricultural Society, 1841-1856
Series X: Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association, 1838-1840
Series XII: Albany Irish Repeal Association, 1843
Series XIV: Deputy Collector and Inspector of District of Genesee, 1832-1842
Series XV: Irish and American Steamship Company, 1851
Series XVI: New York Typographical Society, 1849
Series XVII: Rochester Daily Advertiser, Undated
Series XVIII: Sketches of Rochester, Undated
Series XXII: Personal and Family Papers, 1832-1862

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at The New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: Manuscript Department; call phrase: BV O'Reilly. Correspondence, scrapbooks and bound volumes of assorted historical documents, memoranda and abstracts compiled by Henry O'Reilly; the material dates from 1784 to 1862. The bulk of the correspondence and scrapbooks span the 1840s, while the historical compilations cover the period 1784 through 1820. O'Reilly's scrapbooks address such topics as the development and building of the telegraph, railroad reform, inland navigation, American journalism, agriculture in New York State, and the Civil War. O'Reilly's Western Momentos documents the downfall of the Iroquois, Robert Morris' treaty with the Senecas, and pioneer settlements in New York State. Additional printed materials related to O'Reilly are held in the collections of the New-York Historical Society Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I contains correspondence relating to various business matters from 1837 through 1872.

did.unittitle: Subseries 3: Letters Sent to The New-York Historical Society, 1858-1872
Letters Sent to The New-York Historical Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the O'Reilly Papers falls within this series, the Telegraph Enterprise, which documents the establishment of the electric telegraph system in the United States. In addition to documenting the organization, construction, daily management and progress of various telegraph lines, this series contains material pertaining to the controversies, disputes and litigation in which O'Reilly became involved.

did.abstract: Letters received arranged alphabetically by correspondent; letters sent arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Series III: Demoine Navigation and Railroad Company, 1849-1858
did.abstract: This series documents O'Reilly's activities as secretary of this company, which was organized in 1854 to improve the Demoine Valley.
Letters received arranged alphabetically by correspondent; letters sent arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Arranged chronologically.
Series IV briefly documents O'Reilly's interest in rebuilding and enlarging the Erie Canal.

This series contains documentation on the Clinton League, which was formed in 1859 to protect the New York State canal system from the opposing policies of the state railroad system. This material reflects O'Reilly's activities as chairman of the League.
Letters received arranged alphabetically by correspondent; letters sent arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Series VI: New York State Agricultural Society, 1841-1856
did.abstract: Series VI is comprised of documents pertaining to various activities of the New York State Agricultural Society, of which O'Reilly was recording secretary. It includes material on the New York State Agricultural Fair of 1844.
Series VII documents O'Reilly's activities in New York State politics and his interest in promoting reform in the state and federal governments.
This series contains documents pertaining to O'Reilly's daily activities and duties as Post Master of Rochester. It includes material concerning mail fraud, robberies and abuses in the post office.
Series IX contains material pertaining to O'Reilly's interest in the Rochester public school system and his activities as trustee of School District No. 16 of Rochester.

did.unittitle: Series X: Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association, 1838-1840
did.abstract: This series documents activities of the Rochester Athenaeum and Young Men's Association during O'Reilly's tenure as its president.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of documents pertaining to O'Reilly's interest in purchasing land in Western Virginia.

did.unittitle: Series XII: Albany Irish Repeal Association, 1843
Series XIV: Deputy Collector and Inspector of District of Genesee, 1832-1842
Deputy Collector and Inspector of District of Genesee
Series XV: Irish & American Steamship Company, 1851
Series XVI: New York Typographical Society, 1849
Series XVII: Rochester Daily Advertiser, Undated
Series XVIII: Sketches of Rochester, Undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents concerning O'Reilly's family. It includes two scrapbooks compiled by Henry O'Reilly during the Civil War about his son, Henry Brooks O'Reilly, who was killed in the battle of Williamsburg in 1862.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains a variety of printed material, primarily news clippings, on miscellaneous subjects.
